I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Strengthening Public Resource Management Program. The 
report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) to support implementation of program 
reforms, and if the Board approves the program, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by 
the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
The  program  aims  to  strengthen  public  resource  management  in  Tajikistan  through 
2. 
improved tax policy and administration, more effective and efficient social safety net programs, 
and improved public financial management.1

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
Tajikistan recovered from the economic impacts of the global financial crisis, supported 
3. 
by  (i)  the  Government  of  Tajikistan’s  anti-crisis  program;2 (ii)  a  rebound  in  remittances  (18% 
year-on-year in 2010) resulting principally from the economic upturn in the Russian Federation; 
and (iii) higher global prices for aluminum and cotton, which represented 83% of total exports in 
2010. However, while the real gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate for 2010 was 6.5%—
an increase from 3.4% in 2009—it is still below the 7.4% average growth experienced in 2005–
2008 (Table 1). Recovery continues to be affected by tighter credit to the private sector  due to 
growing  stress  in  the  banking  system, 3 and  the  recent  hike  in  imported  food  prices.  These 
factors are likely to continue restraining real GDP growth in 2011  (forecast at 5.5%)  and 2012 
(forecast  at  6.0%).  Recovery  also  remains  dependent  on  sustained  economic  recovery  in  the 
Russian  Federation,  based  on  Tajikistan’s  reliance  on  trade  and  remittance  inflows.  (See  the 
economic and financial analysis and country economic indicators).4 
 
4. 
Increases in salaries and pensions and higher international commodity prices are expected 
to  keep  inflation  levels  high  (10.0%  estimated  for  2011,  close  to  the  9.8%  figure  of  2010). 5 
Unemployment also remains high (11.5% in 2009), and close to 1 million Tajiks, or about 40% of the 
workforce, work abroad.6 Remittances from migrant workers are the main source of income of many 
families,  averaging  41.1%  of  GDP  in  2005–2009.  Tajikistan  remains  the  poorest  country  in  the 
Commonwealth  of  Independent  States,  with  the  lowest  per  capita  GDP  ($1,900  in  2009)  and  the 
lowest  per  capita  social  expenditures.  The  weak  social  protection  system  offers  limited  social 
assistance  benefits  with  little  impact  on  poverty.  Fiscal  spending  on  social  assistance  (0.5%  of 
GDP) is the lowest in Central Asia.7 Although declining steadily since 1999, poverty remains high,

1. 

Output 1: Selected Aspects of Tax Policy and Administration Improved 

 
13. 
The government is committed to modernizing tax policy and administration. The program 
supports  implementation  of  the  Tax  Administration  Development  Program  for  2011–2015, 
approved  by  the  government  in  2010.  The  Tax  Administration  Development  Program  sets  out 
objectives,  targets,  and  indicative  costs  of  reforms  for  (i)  functional  reorganization  of  the  Tax 
Committee  and  its  offices,  (ii)  introducing  performance  management,  (iii)  building  human 
resources  capacity,  and  (iv)  introducing  information  and  communication  technology  in  the  tax 
system. Under the first tranche, the government has carried out Tax Code amendments which 
(i)  eliminate  selected  value-added  tax  exemptions  (including  on  medical  services  provided  by 
the private sector, sales of handicrafts, and air navigation services) and profit tax exemptions on 
the dividends payable to local enterprises from other local enterprises, (ii) rationalize the rates of 
property  tax  by  removing  a  broad  range  of  rates  and  establishing  single  rates  for  various 
categories of property (commercial, residential, and others), (iii) authorize the Tax Committee to 
develop  procedures  for  electronic  submission  of  tax  returns  to  facilitate  taxpayer  compliance 
with  filing  requirements  and  move  to  a  risk-based  audit  system,  and  (iv) permit  installment 
payments by taxpayers with arrears based on credible financing plans agreed upon between the 
Tax  Committee  and  such  taxpayers.  The  Tax  Committee  has  increased  the  number  of 
taxpayers to be handled by the Large Taxpayers Inspectorate (LTI) by 20% from the baseline of 
December 2010 (from 202 taxpayers to 245), with another increase of 20% planned for 2012 as 
part of the agreed reforms under the second tranche.

Output  2:  Social  Safety  Net  Pilots  Designed,  Implemented,  and  Evaluated 
by the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection  

 
16. 
The  program  will  support  reforms  aimed  at  improving  the  effectiveness,  efficiency,  and 
accountability of public expenditures in social protection, in particular two new pilot programs that 
the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection (MOLSP) has designed and started implementing. The 
phased implementation of the pilot for noncash-based transactions for pension payments through 
individual  bank  accounts  has  been  started  in  four  districts  of  Dushanbe  (Firdawsi,  Shomansur, 
Sino,  and  Somoni),  and  the  cities  of  Kulyab  and  Kurgantyube.  The  MOLSP  will  conduct  an 
independent evaluation of the pilot to (i) determine the improvements in efficiency and quality of 
service  provided  to  pensioners  (including  a gender  analysis  which  assesses  the  impact  on  men 
and  women),  (ii)  determine  the  number  of  ghost  pensioners  identified  and  the  resulting  cost 
savings,  and  (iii)  identify  gaps  and  develop  recommendations  for  improvement.  Requiring 
pensioners  to  use  plastic  cards  is  expected  to  make  payment  of  pensions  more  efficient  and 
reduce  the  average  time  between  release  of  funds  and  the  availability  of  pensions  to 
beneficiaries from to seven days from thirty under the paper-based system. It is also expected 
to  help  reduce  the  number  of  ghost  pensioners  and  other  system  leakages  (e.g.,  informal 
payments to bank tellers). A second pilot will redesign and improve targeting of social assistance 
and  consolidation  of  social  benefits  (subsidies  for  gas,  electricity  and  child  school  education)  to 
approximately 10,000 households in the Yavan district and the town of Istaravshan. The MOLSP 
will  also  conduct  an  independent  evaluation  of  the  second  pilot  program,  including  a  gender 
analysis. Improved targeting of social assistance is expected to help ensure that the benefits are 
given  to  those  that  need  it  most.  This  will  help  improve  the  social  safety  net  systems  in

Over  the  short  term,  the  program  is  designed  to  help  ensure  that  critical  social 
expenditures  are  maintained.  If  such  expenditures  are  not  made,  poverty  incidence  will  be

27. 
Tajikistan’s social situation exhibits certain gender inequalities, which are reflected in the 
delivery  of  social services by  the  social  protection system.  For  example, (i) female  pensioners 
are poorer than male pensioners and depend more on state pensions (women can accumulate 
less  pension  insurance  as  only  14%  of  women  are  in formal  employment  and  women  receive 
less than half of men’s wages on average),29 (ii) households headed by women depend more on 
social  benefits  (11%  of  household  income  comes  from  social  benefits,  compared  to  4%  in 
households  headed  by  men),30 and  (iii)  women  pensioners  make  up  a  majority  of  pensioners 
(56.3% in 2005).31 Women are often not aware of their rights under the social protection system. 
Women in Tajikistan mostly live in households headed by men and thus receive social benefits 
through  the  registered  household  head.  This  dependence  on  the  male  household  head 
becomes  a  constraint  when  male  migrant  workers  leave  behind  their  wives,  sisters,  and 
mothers,  who  then  receive  social  benefits  only  through  the  registered  name  of  their  male 
relatives.  Moreover,  it  is  difficult  to  monitor  and  evaluate  the  gender  impacts  of  the  social 
benefits system as sex-disaggregated indicators do not exist. 
 
28. 
The  program  will  seek  to  address  some  of  these  challenges.  First,  the  Tax  Committee 
will  approve  a  policy  to  train  all  women  professional  and  support  staff  in  the  LTI.  This  should 
improve their chance for career progression in an agency which has very few women at senior 
levels.  Second,  at  least  20%  of  the  members  of  the  Business  Consultative  Group  will  be 
women. Third,  the gender  impact  of  the two pilot  social  service delivery  projects  supported  by 
the program will be analyzed, and recommendations will be made to ensure that gender issues 
are taken into account during project expansion.
